predictions.text: U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) will issue a CSMS message and/or Federal Register notice that establishes a formal process to claim refunds/administrative relief for import duties impacted by the Supreme Court tariff-authority ruling, including at least one stated filing mechanism and effective date.
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if CBP publishes (CSMS and/or Federal Register) formal refund/relief instructions tied to the Supreme Court tariff decision, with an explicit process (e.g., PSC/protest/ACE instructions) and an effective date. Otherwise NO by deadline.
evidence: CNBC report describes Supreme Court rebuke of tariff authority and potential multi-billion dollar refund claims (https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/20/supreme-court-trump-tariff-decision-illegal-refunds.html).
Large-scale duty refunds typically require CBP/Treasury procedural guidance for importers and brokers.
monitoring_signals: CBP CSMS announcements containing keywords: "refund", "reliquidation", "protest", "court decision", "Supreme Court"
Federal Register notices by CBP/Treasury referencing duty refunds or liquidation instructions
Trade law firm client alerts describing new CBP refund workflows
predictions.rationale: If refunds are likely, CBP generally must standardize how claims are filed and processed; the political/legal salience makes procedural guidance probable within months.

predictions.text: The White House (or USTR/Commerce) will publicly transmit to Congress proposed legislation to create or expand executive tariff authority explicitly enabling a broadly applied across-the-board import surcharge (e.g., 10–15% global tariff) after the Supreme Court tariff-authority ruling.
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if an administration legislative proposal (draft bill text, formal transmittal letter, or publicly posted legislative language) is sent to Congress that explicitly authorizes an across-the-board tariff/surcharge (not just targeted product tariffs), and explicitly references the need for authority following the court ruling. Otherwise NO.
evidence: Supreme Court ruling increases judicial risk for tariff implementation under emergency/creative authorities (https://www.nytimes.com/2026/02/21/us/politics/supreme-court-tariffs-conservatives.html).
Trump statement of immediate move to 15% global tariff suggests continued desire for a broad instrument (https://www.nytimes.com/2026/02/21/business/trump-tariffs.html).
monitoring_signals: OMB legislative clearance items and Statements of Administration Policy (SAPs)
USTR/Commerce press briefings referencing "legislative fix" or "tariff authority"
House Ways & Means / Senate Finance introductions aligned with administration messaging
predictions.rationale: A legal setback often triggers an attempt to harden authority via statute, especially if the policy is central to the administration agenda.

predictions.text: At least one major U.S. trading partner (EU, Canada, Mexico, China, Japan, or South Korea) will file a WTO dispute-settlement request for consultations explicitly challenging the U.S. across-the-board 'global tariff' as inconsistent with WTO obligations.
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if the WTO Dispute Settlement page (or the complainant government) lists a 'Request for Consultations' naming the U.S. and explicitly referencing a broadly applied global tariff/surcharge. Otherwise NO.
evidence: Escalation to a 15% global tariff increases formal-trade-law conflict risk (https://www.nytimes.com/2026/02/21/business/trump-tariffs.html).
Retaliation and legal challenges are standard responses for large, non-targeted tariff actions.
monitoring_signals: WTO dispute filings and DS document releases
European Commission DG Trade / Global Affairs Canada statements mentioning WTO action
G7 trade minister communiqués referencing disputes
predictions.rationale: A near-universal tariff is easier to challenge as a systemic breach; WTO consultations are a common first step even alongside retaliation.

predictions.text: DRAMeXchange will report the DDR4 8Gb (or closest standard benchmark) spot price down at least 25% versus its February 2026 monthly average, in any daily print during June 2026.
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if DRAMeXchange benchmark pricing shows a June 2026 daily spot price at least 25% below the February 2026 monthly average for the same DDR4 benchmark. Otherwise NO.
evidence: Report that China's CXMT is offering DDR4 at about half market prices, implying strong downward price pressure (https://www.koreaherald.com/article/10679206).
Commodity memory pricing historically reacts quickly to supply shocks and aggressive undercutting.
monitoring_signals: DRAMeXchange DDR4 spot and contract price updates
Earnings-call commentary from Micron/Samsung/SK hynix on legacy DRAM pricing
Channel checks from PC/OEM procurement and distributor inventory levels
predictions.rationale: If materially under-market supply persists, spot prices often gap down before contracts fully reset.

predictions.text: At least one of Samsung Electronics, SK hynix, or Micron will publicly announce a material curtailment/phase-out of DDR4 output (or an accelerated DDR4 end-of-life roadmap) explicitly citing China-led pricing pressure or DDR4 margin collapse.
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if a press release, earnings-call transcript, investor presentation, or regulatory filing includes an explicit statement about materially cutting DDR4 production or accelerating DDR4 EOL, and ties it to DDR4 pricing/margins and/or China competition. Otherwise NO.
evidence: CXMT DDR4 undercutting raises likelihood of incumbents shifting mix away from legacy nodes (https://www.koreaherald.com/article/10679206).
Major DRAM makers have previously managed cycles via mix shifts and legacy-product reductions.
monitoring_signals: Micron/Samsung/SK hynix earnings transcripts for "DDR4", "legacy", "EOL", "curtail"
Industry analyst notes on wafer allocation shifts to DDR5/HBM
OEM statements about DDR4 availability/allocations
predictions.rationale: Sustained price war in a commoditized segment typically triggers supply discipline and repositioning toward higher-value products.

predictions.text: NASA will officially reschedule Artemis II such that the earliest stated launch date becomes no earlier than 2027-06-30 (i.e., the agency communicates a slip into 2H 2027 or later) due to the reported helium/rocket issues.
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if NASA (press release, briefing, Artemis schedule page, or GAO/NASA OIG-cited NASA date) states Artemis II NET (no-earlier-than) date is 2027-06-30 or later, and links schedule drivers to the helium/vehicle issues. Otherwise NO.
evidence: NYT reports Artemis rocket helium issue delaying Moon mission timelines (https://www.nytimes.com/2026/02/21/science/nasa-artemis-helium-flaw.html).
Artemis schedules have historically been sensitive to hardware and integration issues.
monitoring_signals: NASA Artemis program updates and administrator briefings
GAO/OIG space program schedule oversight publications
Major contractor statements (e.g., Boeing/Lockheed/Northrop) on integration milestones
predictions.rationale: A disclosed technical flaw often propagates into official schedule updates within one to two quarters.

predictions.text: At least one of Delta, United, or American will disclose a quantified financial impact of at least $100 million (pre-tax or operating) from the February 2026 East Coast blizzard disruptions in an SEC filing, earnings release, or earnings-call prepared remarks.
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if a covered airline explicitly attributes >=$100 million impact to the Feb 2026 blizzard (cancellations/irregular operations) in an SEC filing or earnings materials. Otherwise NO.
evidence: CNBC reports major East Coast blizzard driving flight cancellations and operational disruption (https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/21/blizzard-prompts-airlines-waive-flight-change-fees.html).
Large irregular-ops events can create substantial costs (reaccommodation, crews, maintenance positioning).
monitoring_signals: 8-K filings and earnings-call transcripts mentioning "blizzard" or "winter storm"
BTS on-time performance and cancellation data for affected carriers
Airline guidance updates and investor presentations
predictions.rationale: If disruption was large enough, carriers often quantify it when updating quarterly performance or guidance.

predictions.text: ICE Dutch TTF natural gas front-month futures will settle above €60/MWh on at least one trading day.
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if the ICE End-of-Day settlement for Dutch TTF front-month exceeds €60.00/MWh at least once by the deadline. Otherwise NO.
evidence: Escalating Middle East conflict risk raises tail risk for LNG flows and risk premiums (https://www.nytimes.com/2026/02/21/world/middleeast/iran-military-operation-venezuela.html).
European gas prices remain sensitive to global LNG disruptions and shipping risk.
monitoring_signals: ICE TTF settlements and implied volatility
LNG freight/insurance costs and rerouting reports
EU storage trajectory vs seasonal norms and LNG send-out rates
predictions.rationale: Even without a sustained disruption, geopolitical shocks can trigger short-lived price spikes above key thresholds.

predictions.text: BLS will report U.S. Import Price Index (excluding petroleum) year-over-year inflation at or above +4.0% in at least one monthly Import/Export Price Index release.
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if any BLS monthly release shows Import Price Index ex petroleum (not seasonally adjusted series as published by BLS) with YoY change >= +4.0%. Otherwise NO by deadline.
evidence: Tariff escalation to 15% implies higher landed import costs and pass-through risk (https://www.nytimes.com/2026/02/21/business/trump-tariffs.html).
Trade policy shocks often appear first in import-price measures before broader consumer prices.
monitoring_signals: BLS Import/Export Price Index releases (ex petroleum import index)
USD trade-weighted index and ocean freight indices
Retailer/OEM price increase announcements citing tariffs
predictions.rationale: A broad tariff plus supply-chain repricing can lift non-petroleum import prices meaningfully within 3–6 months.
